metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (automatic weather station of Huazhaizi desert steppe station, 2016)
metadata.description:
This data set contains meteorological element observation data of huazhaizi desert station in the middle reaches of heihe hydrological meteorological observation network from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016.The station is located in huazhaizi, zhangye city, gansu province.The latitude and longitude of huazhaizi station is 100.3201E, 38.7659N and 1731m above sea level.The observation items include: air temperature and relative humidity sensors at 5m and 10m, facing due north;Install the barometer inside the waterproof box;The tilting bucket rain gauge is installed at 10m;The wind speed and direction sensor is set at 5m and 10m, facing due north;The four-component radiometer is installed at 6m, facing due south;Two infrared thermometers are installed at 6m, facing due south, and the probe facing vertically downward;The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm of the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil water sensor is buried 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil hot plates (3 pieces) are buried 6cm underground.Specific observation elements are as follows:
Air temperature and humidity (Ta_5m RH_5m Ta_10m, RH_10m) (unit: c, percentage), pressure (Press) (unit: hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_5m, WS_10m) (unit: m/s), wind (WD_10m) (unit: degrees), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:C), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (in watts/m2), soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_60cm, Ms_100cm) (unit: volumetric water content, percentage), and soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_60cm, Ts_100cm) (unit: Celsius).
Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data elements of observation data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;Due to the problem of the wind speed and direction sensor, the observed wind speed of 10m was missing between December and January 29, 2016;The data of soil heat flux G2 was missing from July 5 to August 17 due to the probe problem.(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2016-6-10-10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Li et al. (2013), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in data collection for estimating evapotranspiration in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in this domain is the difficulty in accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area, where the eddy covariance flux measurements of sensible heat (H) and latent heat (LE) have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy. Additionally, errors in derived component temperatures, caused by image classification errors and other factors, pose significant challenges.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used for studying evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Example.Answer: A dataset example for studying evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces is from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER), which includes a multiscale dataset obtained from an oasis-desert area. This dataset comprises flux observation matrix data from eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using a two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Definition.Answer: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model is significant for estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration because it accounts for the heterogeneity of land surfaces by considering both soil and vegetation components separately. This model helps in accurately estimating surface evapotranspiration, which is crucial for understanding the terrestrial water cycle and managing water resources.

Definition.Question: How does the HiWATER experiment contribute to the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Definition.Answer: The HiWATER experiment contributes to understanding eco-hydrological processes by providing multiscale and multidisciplinary data through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales. It offers a comprehensive observation system including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, which capture interactions between oasis and desert ecosystems and help address challenges in upscaling processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced during the data collection for evapotranspiration estimation in arid regions versus oasis-desert interactions in eco-hydrological studies?
Comparison.Answer: For evapotranspiration estimation in arid regions, challenges include the difficulty of ground measurements of evaporation and transpiration, especially due to image classification errors and the need for accurate temperature separation. In contrast, data collection for oasis-desert interactions faces challenges related to the poor availability of multiscale observations and environmental degradation issues, such as drying rivers and degraded vegetation, impacting the stability of ecological observations.

Interpretation.Question: How might the hierarchical instrumentation on nested scales contribute to understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: The hierarchical instrumentation on nested scales allows for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments in the oasis-desert system. This structure helps in collecting data at various scales, providing a comprehensive understanding of interactions between different landscapes, such as sandy deserts, desert pavements, and irrigated farmland. Such a detailed dataset can improve model accuracy and reveal intricate patterns in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, supporting ecological security and sustainable development in oasis areas.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection might arise from attempting to measure energy and water vapor exchange in strongly advective agricultural areas, and how can these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: In strongly advective agricultural areas, challenges include incomplete energy balance closure and errors in surface-air temperature difference measurements. These can be addressed by using robust models like the TSEB model, which requires accurate component temperature calculations to estimate energy and water vapor exchanges. Ground-based measurements, such as those from eddy covariance systems, along with high-resolution thermal imagery, can help refine these estimates by providing detailed input data that accounts for the advective influences.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors contributing to challenges in estimating surface fluxes include the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy, uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, errors in determining soil and vegetation component temperatures, and strong advective environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to achieve a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable oasis development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in balancing oasis and desert systems arises from ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms, particularly in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The poor availability of multiscale observations is due to the complexity of capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and the lack of instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to provide comprehensive data across different landscapes and conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating multiscale observations in understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiscale observations can enhance the understanding of eco-hydrological processes by providing comprehensive data across different scales and disciplines. This approach can help overcome the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations, thereby improving the recognition of oasis-desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the impact on data quality when employing a series of data processing techniques for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a series of data processing techniques could improve data quality by ensuring accurate and reliable measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. It involves careful quality control through sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and archiving, which are essential for maintaining the integrity and usability of the datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the outcomes of using high-precision thermal infrared cameras for separating soil and vegetation component temperatures in strongly advective agricultural areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-precision thermal infrared cameras to separate soil and vegetation component temperatures can lead to reliable estimates of evaporation and transpiration ratios, as well as latent heat fluxes. This method helps in accurately partitioning evapotranspiration into its components, thus improving the performance of models like TSEB in such environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of employing a two-source energy balance model for estimating evapotranspiration in vegetation-covered landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to improve the estimation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration, which are crucial for understanding the terrestrial water cycle and managing water resources. The model aims to account for the heterogeneous nature of soil and vegetation surfaces, providing more accurate surface evapotranspiration estimates compared to one-source models.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of maintaining long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to support the ecological security and sustainable development of oases by understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics. Long-term observations are essential for recognizing oasis-desert interactions, achieving carbon neutrality goals, and mitigating ecological degradation challenges in inland river basins.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What techniques and instruments are used to measure soil temperature and moisture at various depths in an arid region observational network?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The observational network employs soil temperature probes buried at the surface and at various depths (2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm, and 100cm) and soil moisture sensors at similar depths. These sensors are positioned at a distance of 2m south of the meteorological tower to ensure accurate readings.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are meteorological parameters such as air temperature, wind speed, and radiation systematically observed and recorded in a hydrometeorological study?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological parameters are recorded every 10 minutes using sensors mounted at different heights on a meteorological tower. These include air temperature and humidity sensors at 5m and 10m, anemometers for wind speed at 5m and 10m, and a four-component radiometer at 6m for radiation measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the process involved in ensuring data quality control and handling missing or erroneous data in a large-scale hydrometeorological dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality control involves multiple steps: ensuring the presence of 144 data entries per day, marking missing data with a specified value (-6999), removing duplicate records, and deleting data outside physical meaning or instrument range. Additionally, any data with potential issues are highlighted, and a consistent date-time format is maintained.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for effectively using thermal infrared cameras to capture soil and canopy component temperatures in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Effective use of thermal infrared cameras requires a stable platform for mounting the camera, appropriate calibration to account for atmospheric effects, and clear sky conditions to ensure accurate temperature readings. Additionally, high-resolution imagery is necessary to differentiate between soil and canopy components, and classification methods such as the maximum-likelihood method are needed to separate and analyze these components accurately.

Enablement.Question: In what ways can a multiscale observation system enhance the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: A multiscale observation system enables a comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes by integrating data from various scales, such as flux observation matrices, remote sensing instruments, and ground measurements. This approach captures interactions between different landscape components, providing detailed insights into energy, water, and carbon exchanges and facilitating the development of scalable models that address the complexities of oasis-desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Answer: Progress is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a significant challenge in the field. The complexity of capturing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces requires instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain comprehensive data.

Expectation.Question: Why might comprehensive datasets involving energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange be critical for understanding oasis-desert interactions?
Expectation.Answer: Comprehensive datasets are crucial because understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems is essential for achieving sustainable development. Such datasets allow for the recognition of oasis-desert interactions, which is significant for ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, such as those used in the HiWATER experiment, utilize hierarchically nested scales and a combination of ground-based and remote sensing technologies to address the challenge of capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes. By integrating eddy covariance towers, meteorological stations, and advanced remote sensing techniques like LiDAR and thermal imaging, these methods effectively capture data across different scales and landscapes, offering a comprehensive approach to understanding eco-hydrological interactions.

Judgmental.Question: How might data collection strategies be improved to better support long-term monitoring of oasis–desert interactions and their impact on carbon cycles?
Judgmental.Answer: Improving data collection strategies could involve expanding the network of observation stations to cover more diverse landscapes within oasis-desert systems and incorporating more advanced technologies to measure carbon fluxes accurately. Long-term monitoring can be enhanced by integrating satellite-based observations with ground-based data, ensuring comprehensive spatial and temporal coverage. Additionally, employing machine learning techniques to analyze and predict trends from the collected data could provide deeper insights into oasis-desert interactions and their impact on carbon cycles.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how component temperatures of soil and vegetation are accurately determined in a strongly advective agricultural area.
Assertion.Answer: Component temperatures of soil and vegetation are determined using thermal infrared cameras, with images classified into soil and canopy pixels. The component temperatures are calculated by converting thermal infrared temperatures to radiometric temperatures, validated against surface temperatures observed by a four-component radiometer.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in the data collection process for eco-hydrological observations in oasis-desert systems and propose potential solutions to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert systems include the poor availability of multiscale observations and the ecological degradation in arid areas. Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the effectiveness of different data collection methods used for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid regions, particularly in oasis-desert areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods in arid regions, especially oasis-desert areas, involve using eddy covariance systems, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations to measure energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These are supplemented by hydrometeorological data and remote sensing tools like LiDAR and thermal imagers. The effectiveness lies in their ability to provide comprehensive datasets that cover both the spatial and temporal dynamics necessary to understand these fluxes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose strategies for enhancing the quality and reliability of datasets related to hydrometeorological observations in arid and semiarid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Enhancing the quality and reliability of datasets can be achieved through meticulous quality control measures, including sensor calibration, data processing, and error checking. Implementing a combination of high-resolution airborne remote sensing and synchronized ground measurements, as well as ensuring data sharing through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, can further improve dataset reliability and accessibility.
